subject: Re: [junit] Re: Problems with assertEquals()
msgSnippet: Heh, to quote Yogi Berra, It s like Deja Vu all over again Just like the test name often needs further clarification (never pass up an oportunity for
messageBody:
Heh, to quote Yogi Berra, "It's like Deja Vu all over again"

Just like the test name often needs further clarification (never pass
up an oportunity for documentation), often the reason for the
assertion is not self-apparent. You can try to argue that "it ought
to be, or rewrite your code!" but, as before, I think you're straying
too close to the "Java code is self-documenting" argument, which I
find ... dubious at best.

It makes your test reports clearer when failures occur I prefer to
see "Wrong number of Login attempts recorded ..." rather than
"testValidLogin.assertEquals failed ... " As a result I often don't
even have to look at the test code to fix the problem. Without
messages, I have to at the very least go and look to see what the
assertion's variables are named before I can begin fixing the problem.

It's also easier to write a short sentence about what's being asserted
than it is to be sure that you've chosen values and variable names
such that future readers can divine their purpose. That's a valuable
task as well, but for the time involved, there's no reason you can't
write a little text as well. Or to put it pithily:

I feel that I'm proficient with Java, but when I want to explain
something, especially *why* something, I generally prefer English.

-Kevin

On Tue, 01 Mar 2005 22:24:06 -0600, J. B. Rainsberger
<jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Kevin Klinemeier wrote:
> > Of course, not having a message may affect the result of your
> > interactions with other developers. If you don't have a message on
> > your assertions in my projects, our interaction may revolve around a
> > large bat. :P
>
> Really. I'm surprised. Doesn't the test case name tell you everything
> you need to know?
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
